unit_learning_outcomes.description: Explain the role of regional states and intergovernmental organisations in maintaining Indo-Pacific security.
Contrast Australian regional security interests with the interests of other Indo-Pacific states.
Identify and explain potential flash points for regional conflict and insecurity.
Demonstrate understanding of the key security challenges and drivers of insecurity in the contemporary Indo-Pacific region.
Describe Australia's position and its security concerns in relation to the Indo-Pacific region.
Identify key actors in the Indo-Pacific region, and understand their interests and strategies.

non_scheduled_learning_activities.description: Students are expected to complete assigned readings and watch lecture recordings prior to their tutorial each week. The estimated time for class preparation is three hours per week for Week 2 through Week 13. No class preparation is required in Week 1.

assessments.description: Students will write a country brief on a regional actor and use one data set to demonstrate the strength or weakness of the chosen actor.
This take home exam will consist of four short essay questions, each to be answered with a maximum of 500 words.
Students will complete five quizzes throughout the unit, each worth 6%.

data.subject_search_title: PICX1012 - Strategy and Security in the Indo-Pacific

academic_org.value: Department of Security Studies and Criminology

data.description: This unit exposes students to the key strategic trends in the Indo-Pacific region. It looks at the rise of China and India as emerging regional great powers, and the response by other major players, including the United States and Japan. It introduces students with the most pressing traditional and non-traditional security challenges facing the region today. It also provides students with the conceptual and empirical understanding of Australia's role, interests and instruments in regional security and stability. The unit also introduces students to the diverse non-traditional challenges influencing Indo-Pacific region. The unit concludes with an assessment of the sources and consequences of key regional actors that influence security and prosperity in the twenty-first century.
